title: NBC journalist’s son interrupts live segment on Turkey, Syria conflict
text:
A TV anchor has been interrupted by her young son while delivering a live broadcast in a cute “mum moment” that went quickly viral.

NBC News correspondent Courtney Kube, who covers the Pentagon and national security issues, was discussing Turkey’s invasion of Syria in an interview on Wednesday when her young son walked up to try to grab his mother’s attention.

“Excuse me, my kids are here,” she said. “Live television.”

She later told NBC News, “Breaking news in Syria didn’t line up with preschool drop-off, so he and his twin brother were with me.”

The video, which has been viewed more than 1.6 million times, is reminiscent of the viral “BBC Dad” from 2017 whose Skype interview was gatecrashed by his young children.

“Sometimes unexpected breaking news happens while you’re reporting breaking news,” MSNBC tweeted with the hashtags “#MSNBCMoms #workingmoms”.

Proof that @ckubeNBC is the hardest working mom in the Pentagon press corps and all the while consistently breaks news. Goals. https://t.co/Rl2PjqrQuC — Amanda Macias (@amanda_m_macias) October 9, 2019

Her colleague, CNBC national security reporter Amanda Macias, then tweeted the video, writing, “Proof that @ckubeNBC is the hardest working mom in the Pentagon press corps and all the while consistently breaks news. Goals.”

As the adorable viral moment was unfolding, however, the two women were being dragged into a major scandal.

On Wednesday, US authorities arrested a counter-terrorism analyst at the US Defence Intelligence Agency (DIA) and charged him with leaking to the two journalists in 2018 and 2019.

Henry Kyle Frese, 30, of Alexandria, Virginia, was taken into custody when he arrived at work and faces two counts of revealing classified defence information to persons not entitled to receive it.

The Justice Department did not reveal the content of the information allegedly leaked by Mr Frese other than to say it concerned a “foreign country’s weapons systems”.

“Frese was caught red-handed disclosing sensitive national security information for personal gain,” Assistant Attorney-General for National Security John C. Demers said in a statement.

“Frese betrayed the trust placed in him by the American people — a betrayal that risked harming the national security of this country. This is one of six unauthorised disclosure cases the department has charged in just over two years, and we will continue in our efforts to punish and deter this behaviour.”

Mr Frese was a contractor with the DIA from January 2017 to February 2018 and a full-fledged DIA employee since then with clearance ranging up to the top-secret level, officials said. The DIA is the US military’s intelligence service.

Great. via @CNN US Officials say "a new leaker is exposing national security documents." #OPSEC #NationalSecurity — Kyle Frese (@HKFrese) August 5, 2014

One of the reporters to whom DIA official @HKFrese allegedly leaked top secret intel posted a picture of the two drinking and partying together at the German embassy in 2017. Per the federal affidavit, the two were romantically involved and lived together for a year. #OPSEC pic.twitter.com/niodUwPLsU — Sean Davis (@seanmdav) October 9, 2019

This seems to be one of the tweets referenced in the indictment of DIA analyst Henry Kyle Frese. pic.twitter.com/yPaur8Wdm4 — Chuck Ross (@ChuckRossDC) October 9, 2019

In April or May of last year, Mr Frese allegedly accessed an intelligence report “unrelated to his job duties on multiple occasions” and passed on information to one of the journalists, according to the indictment.

While not named in the indictment, Macias and Kube are identifiable as the two journalists who received the information, with public tweets cited in the court filings corresponding to tweets sent by the pair.

Macias and Frese had the same residential address from August 2017 until August 2018, the DOJ said, and “based on reviews of Frese’s and Journalist 1’s public social media pages, it appears that they were involved in a romantic relationship for some or all of that period of time”.

In May 2018, Macias wrote a story for CNBC citing “sources with direct knowledge of US intelligence reports” that China had installed anti-ship cruise missiles and surface-to-air missile systems on the contested Spratly Islands.

According to the indictment, Macias wrote to Mr Frese in April last year to ask whether he would be willing to speak to Kube. Frese stated that he was “down” to help Kube if it helped Macias because he wanted to see Macias “progress”.

In July, she tweeted, “NBC’s @ckubeNBC and I break in our first shared byline. Beijing is in the midst of conducting a series of anti-ship missile tests in the South China Sea. These contested waters serve as a gateway to global sea routes where approximately $US3.4 trillion in trade pass annually.”

According to the indictment, Mr Frese’s mobile phone was being monitored and he was heard last month transmitting classified information to Kube.

Mr Frese goes by the name “Kyle Frese” on Twitter, where he often retweeted Macias’ stories and previously mocked US President Donald Trump for not understanding “OPSEC”, or operations security.

Just last month he appeared to attack NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden, writing, “I suppose you of all people, would be a good judge of what information is too dangerous to be released?”

Mr Frese could face up to 10 years in prison for each count of transmitting classified information if convicted.

Last year, Senate Intelligence Committee staffer James Wolfe was arrested and charged with lying to investigators about his contacts with three reporters, one of whom he was allegedly in a romantic relationship with.

New York Times reporter Ali Watkins had previously tweeted about wanting to be like the character Zoe Barnes, from political drama House of Cards, who sleeps with Kevin Spacey’s character to get stories.

— with AFP
